review_title: Struggling to Reach an Acceptable Baseline

There is often work available. High turn-over and low pay make it so that jobs frequently come open. If you are in a tough spot, working for NOLS is an almost guaranteed option. Housing is provided at a low cost.

Access to gear and backcountry expertise. There are some pretty great people that pass through the NOLS ecosystem
cons:
High Turnover - few people really know what they are doing
Laughable Compensation - I mostly work here because I am in school and housing is provided
Inconsistent Hours
Few Opportunities for Professional Growth

review_title: Good culture, reasonable hours, great people
pros:
NOLS has locations around the world, but this is about Lander. If you want the small mountain-town lifestyle (without many tourists), NOLS is great. But rural Wyoming isn't for everyone. 

The NOLS community is extremely welcoming (it leans a bit liberal). Decent benefits for a non-profit, including pro deals on lots of outdoor gear. NOLS is better organized than many for-profit small- or medium-businesses.

NOLS takes leadership seriously. Leadership is above average and focus is on students (while being financially responsible). No quarterly earnings insanity.
cons:
You can make more money elsewhere (but probably with more stress).

NOLS takes leadership seriously, but the community can wallow in consensus building at times. The result is usually (but not always) worth it, but still slow.

If you're not native to Lander family and friends may rarely visit ... Lander isn't an easy place to get to. Because of this, Lander can be transient, but many people find it amazing after a few years.

NOLS has a few (but not many) challenging, satisfying jobs. If you start out in the bottom ranks you can move pretty quickly, but openings are fewer and farther between as you rise. Partners of NOLS staff sometimes struggle to find engaging work around Lander (except for doctors, nurses, and the like).

review_title: Huge gap between expedition and HQ culture
job_title: Faculty in Fort Mc Clellan, AL
pros: Field courses and WMI courses are fantastic educational opportunities, truly life changing. Leadership offered by field/WMI staff, and experienced by students is awesome.
cons: HQ leadership doesn't practice what NOLS preaches. Insular, myopic, and arrogant. They're grabbing at bright shiny things like new official color, name, and flimsy re-definition of core elements of school instead of dealing with the harder, deeper issues that plague the organization. Understandable since the issues revolve around personalities of HQ leadership. Sure, that's hard but shouldn't leaders of a leadership school provide themselves the most scrutiny and demand the highest level of growth and development?

pros:
-NOLS is the best in what we were founded on - teaching students in the backcountry. 
-Being involved with positive student experiences is really satisfying 
-In-town jobs at a NOLS location could be nice (avoid HQ)
cons:
- everyone is replaceable and they treat you that way
-If you are looking at jobs in Marketing + Admissions, do not waste your time. It is not worth the headache of moving out to the middle of Wyoming.
- You will make under $30,000 and that seems to be accepted as normal, while the directors will make over $100,000.
-Admissions and Marketing will suck the life out of anyone who is excited to learn and be creative. You will be tied down to customer service tasks.
-There is no leadership in the office. there could not be a bigger gap between what we teach in the field and what we live in the office.
-departments don't get along. there are managers in different departments that can barely speak to each other.

review_title: Great Culture, But Hard to Live on the Pay
pros: Work with smart, talented, hard-working people who care about the wilderness and student outcomes. Flexible work hours in some departments. You can take off early on a Friday to rock climb, but you must make sure your work is done first. Work hard and play hard.
cons: Unfortunately, it is hard to live on the pay and you are required to "do it all." Working with limited budgets and a full plate of work, if you don't do it, it won't happen.

job_title: Administrative Assistant/Office Manager in Lander, WY
pros: There is a lot of opportunity for lateral movement within the school. You can learn about many departments quickly.  Employees can take leisurely lunches in order to take a run or go ride a bike.
cons:
Painfully low pay.
Job titles don't reflect the work performed.
Turnover is high. 
There isn't any room for upward mobility.

pros:
-Some excellent co-instructors and opportunities to visit amazing places.
-Opportunities to develop new skills.
-Feedback can offer great insight into one's performance and areas of growth.
-The school is trying to balance a lot - growth, custom contracts, different skill areas, a dynamic global economic context, etc.
cons:
-It is hard to get consistent work, and there can be a lot of uncertainty.
-Too many new instructors every year make it a culture of scarcity.  The school has this setup by design, and it was demoralizing to realize that fact.    
-The above point has made me feel unappreciated, and completely like a cog in the machine.
-Sometimes admin and program supervisors don't set an instructor up for success (ie, an inexperienced instructor team, unprepared students, etc.), and then don't take any responsibility for course outcomes not being as high as if those challenges weren't in place.
-The pay is abysmal, even within the industry.
-The school is riding off its reputation and the enthusiasm of those who have had great experiences as students (of which there are many, which is typically a great thing).  Yet, without investing in staff, without making folks feel valued and secure, and without providing a reasonable way to make a living, standards will continue to slowly yet consistently slip, until there are more major negative consequences (like a fatality or fatalities) that force a deep introspective reexamination of the processes that the school has relied upon up to this point.  
-The steady increase in NOLS Pro courses create compromised course experiences of the school's product for outside client desires.
-While the school touts itself as growth oriented, instructors who admit mistakes or are open about growth needs are penalized for doing so.  

TL;DR: The school provides wonderful opportunities for student experiences for a LOT of students, but is not a supportive, financially feasible, smart long-term career choice for instructors.  Instructing will come with a scarcity of work, a lot of stress about financial security, and a feeling of being completely replaceable.

review_title: Ineffective senior leadership, overt expedition bias
pros: NOLS custom, Risk Services, and NOLS Wilderness Medicine are led by dynamic, thoughtful personalities and are driving a culture of excellence and innovation. The real heart of NOLS is alive and well in these pillars. If you can, find a position with these teams. The culture of risk management in the field is noteworthy and is perhaps the field community's strongest asset.
cons: Everything you've read above is absolutely true and does not need repeating. Well, except for the compensation. It's abysmal and there are no formal cost-of-living adjustments so be prepared to earn less next year than you did this year. If you work for an entity other than expeditions, you can expect to be treated as a second-class citizen. NOLS expeditions is a failing brand that lacks a consistent mission  or even a clear curriculum. Ask any field instructor (lovely, hard-working people) what the purpose of a NOLS field course is and you'll get a range of answers because no one actually knows. Field instructors deserve better than this. No wonder folks are hesitant to part with thousands of dollars to send their child on a field course. The current emphasis on social justice work detracts from the actual mission of the school and is not mentioned in the field catalog. A student shows up wanting to climb a peak or boat a river and is instead forced to sit through lectures about how they should feel bad because they are privileged and fragile. As a conservative and a person of faith I don't feel safe when working NOLS field courses. In briefings and debriefings I routinely hear comments made by leadership that run counter to my closely held beliefs and I can't say anything because I'm afraid to be branded as "un-inclusive".

pros: Fun work environment, casual dress code, work-life balance (although you don't have much money for the life part)
cons: Isolating location, poor pay, high turnover, politics discussed freely and openly--very obvious where the school stands in regard to what political opinion you should have

pros: Strong management. Excellent financial management and policies. Very dedicated employees to mission and student experiences. NOLS is an excellent place to work and your contribution as a staff member is clearly appreciated and valued. Very participative management style of senior leadership.
cons: Salaries are not high but ok.
